Award.AwardTitle: STEM Scholars: Attracting and Retaining Students in Science and Mathematics Majors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Transylvania University (TU) STEM Scholars Program provides four years of support to two cohorts of freshmen entering in successive years, with up to 15 students comprising each cohort. Participants in the TU STEM Scholars Program are recruited from students who are intended majors in biology, chemistry, computer science, mathematics, physics, neuroscience or environmental science. In addition to the financial support from the S-STEM scholarships, program activities to recruit and retain students include personalized mentoring and advising by STEM faculty members, workshops on quantitative reasoning and learning habits, scientific lectures, a science and math journal club, summer research experiences, and presentations on STEM career opportunities.

Intellectual Merit: Through the various cohort-building activities and other support mechanisms provided the students selected to participate in the TU STEM Scholars Program, this project contributes to the knowledge base of effective recruitment and retention strategies for undergraduate STEM students. The fusion of existing TU student services with those developed through this project provides a model for other similar institutions.

Broader Impacts: The S-STEM scholarships allow students from disadvantaged socioeconomic backgrounds to pursue an education as a major in a STEM discipline at a private liberal arts university. More than one-third of recent incoming students to Transylvania are first generation college students. Thus, the TU STEM Scholars Program is broadening participation to individuals who otherwise may not have had opportunities to become STEM professionals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Transylvania STEM Scholars program sought to increase student retention in STEM fields through supplemental scholarships, by reducing the need to work off campus. We also supported a community of connected learners through workshops, alumni mentors in STEM fields, and research, shadowing, and internship experiences. We set ambitious goals of  increasing by 5 to 10 the number of students selecting a STEM major and increasing the retention to degree achievement by 20%. We exceeded these goals increasing the number of students declaring an interest in STEM fields from 94 (30% of incoming class) prior to the grant to 120 (40% of incoming class) during the grant. The percentage of all students graduating from Transylvania with a STEM degree increased from 25.7% prior to the grant  to 30.5% for the two graduating classes of STEM Scholars. Our ultimate goal was to ensure that more students would enter the STEM workforce or graduate school after graduation. Of the students who participated in the STEM Scholars program through all four years, 79% have gained admission to or are actively applying to STEM-related graduate programs. The remaining 21% of STEM Scholars are currently employed in STEM fields. The impacts of this grant reach far beyond the students supported by the grant. The vast majority of Transylvania’s student body derives from Appalachia and rural regions of Kentucky, Ohio, Indiana, and Tennessee with most students hoping to return to their communities. This grant will increase the number of STEM professionals in these rural regions.
